channel.title: Comments on: WordPress Theme Authors, Don’t Forget The wp_head() Function

item.title: By: Ria
item.dc:creator: Ria
item.description:
I am still unable to get this to work on my blog site. The area for the sidebar shows up. But the actual sidebar doesn't. I have an area for designating the widget areas and have activated use of sidebar (Posts) in post and pages. I have tried putting [sourcecode lang=‚Äùphp‚Äù] wp_head(); [/sourcecode]
in the header and the code actually shows up in the header. What amd I doing wrong?
item.content:encoded:
I am still unable to get this to work on my blog site. The area for the sidebar shows up. But the actual sidebar doesn’t. I have an area for designating the widget areas and have activated use of sidebar (Posts) in post and pages. I have tried putting
[sourcecode lang=‚Äùphp‚Äù]
wp_head();
[/sourcecode]

in the header and the code actually shows up in the header. What amd I doing wrong?

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2009/04/08/wordpress-theme-authors-dont-forget-the-wp_head-function/#comment-2958">syndrael</a>.
Sounds like you've got something hooking into wp_head that is taking a long time to process. Could be a plugin or theme.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to syndrael.

Sounds like you’ve got something hooking into wp_head that is taking a long time to process. Could be a plugin or theme.

item.title: By: syndrael
item.dc:creator: syndrael
item.description: wp_head makes my site very slow. In average, 2.5 seconds on 3.6 needed for the whole page. I've removed action in wp_head (may be the list useful) but i can't resolve this problem. Any ideas ? Best regards from Paris, France
item.content:encoded:
wp_head makes my site very slow. In average, 2.5 seconds on 3.6 needed for the whole page.
I’ve removed action in wp_head (may be the list useful) but i can’t resolve this problem.
Any ideas ?
Best regards from Paris, France

item.title: By: Jue
item.dc:creator: Jue
item.description: Thank you, this cleared up a problem I had with the WP-Polls plugin. I had removed BOTH wp_head and wp_footer from my template a long time ago when I knew much less about theming, and only recently have begun to pay for it with mysterious plugin problems. This warning should be emblazoned on EVERY beginner themer's guide out there.
item.content:encoded: Thank you, this cleared up a problem I had with the WP-Polls plugin. I had removed BOTH wp_head and wp_footer from my template a long time ago when I knew much less about theming, and only recently have begun to pay for it with mysterious plugin problems. This warning should be emblazoned on EVERY beginner themer’s guide out there.

item.description: Thank you!! You fixed my problem! I had edited my Header and took the tag out
item.content:encoded: Thank you!! You fixed my problem! I had edited my Header and took the tag out

item.title: By: Joseph Scott
item.dc:creator: Joseph Scott
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2009/04/08/wordpress-theme-authors-dont-forget-the-wp_head-function/#comment-2951">Thom Allen</a>.
I don't think any of the default actions (see wp-includes/default-filters.php) will change the styling at all. Any theme that doesn't call wp_head() should be considered broken. There are core features of WordPress that require it in order to work. In addition to RSD there's: wp_enqueue_scripts (makes sure the correct Javascript files get included in pages), WLW manifest file (tells Windows Live Writer what features WP supports) and comment threading Javascript. That isn't a complete list, just the highlights.
There are also plugins that make us of wp_head() as well.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Thom Allen.

I don’t think any of the default actions (see wp-includes/default-filters.php) will change the styling at all. Any theme that doesn’t call wp_head() should be considered broken. There are core features of WordPress that require it in order to work. In addition to RSD there’s: wp_enqueue_scripts (makes sure the correct Javascript files get included in pages), WLW manifest file (tells Windows Live Writer what features WP supports) and comment threading Javascript. That isn’t a complete list, just the highlights.

There are also plugins that make us of wp_head() as well.

item.title: By: Thom Allen
item.dc:creator: Thom Allen
item.description: Will using wp_head() cause any styling issues? or is it simply giving the theme access to internal WordPress functionality?
item.content:encoded: Will using wp_head() cause any styling issues? or is it simply giving the theme access to internal WordPress functionality?
